image.altText: Mother holds child in front of hospital equipment as child cries

items.synopsis: Hundreds of people are believed to be dead after a blast at a crammed Gaza hospital that Israel and Palestinian militants are blaming on each other, while regional leaders postpone meetings with Joe Biden ahead of his visit to Israel.

title.children: Hundreds feared dead after Gaza hospital explosion as Joe Biden heads to Israel

image.altText: Three children sit on a hospital bed, visibly upset

items.synopsis: Former Israeli negotiator Daniel Levy says intentionally targeting a hospital where civilians were sheltering was a war crime, while 22 Arab members of the United Nations demand an immediate ceasefire in Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: Former peace negotiator says 'everyone on a path to hell' following Gaza hospital blast as Arab nations demand ceasefire

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli government has announced what it has described as a "humanitarian zone" in southern Gaza. In statements just published on X, the government's unit responsible for the "Coordination of Government Activities in the Territories" (COGAT) said Israel's defence forces has called on Gaza residents to evacuate to an area near the city of Khan Younis. "The IDF calls on #GazaCity residents to evacuate south for their protection," COGAT said on X. "Al-Mawasi is where international #HumanitarianAid will be provided as needed." According to the United Nations' Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, Al-Mawasi "is a Bedouin Palestinian town on the southern coast of the Gaza Strip, approximately one kilometre wide and fourteen kilometres long".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel announces 'humanitarian zone' in southern Gaza

children.content: The Israeli government has announced what it has described as a "humanitarian zone" in southern Gaza.

In statements just published on X, the government's unit responsible for the "Coordination of Government Activities in the Territories" (COGAT) said Israel's defence forces has called on Gaza residents to evacuate to an area near the city of Khan Younis.

props.alt: A map of part of Gaza.

children.content: A map showing the zone.
(X: COGAT)
"The IDF calls on #GazaCity residents to evacuate south for their protection," COGAT said on X.
"Al-Mawasi is where international #HumanitarianAid will be provided as needed."
According to the United Nations'
Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, Al-Mawasi "is a Bedouin Palestinian town on the southern coast of the Gaza Strip, approximately one kilometre wide and fourteen kilometres long".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese commented on the Gaza hospital blast during a joint press conference with Fijian Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka, who is visiting Canberra. "We have seen a devastating loss of innocent life since the attacks on Israel by the terrorist group Hamas," Mr Albanese said. "The scenes from the explosion at a Gaza City hospital are deeply distressing and it is clear that there has been a devastating loss of life. "Every innocent life matters, whether it is Israeli or Palestinian. "Our thoughts are with those killed, those injured and their loved ones. The protection of civilian lives must come first, as the parliament said in its resolution that we carried on Monday, and respect for international humanitarian law is paramount. "We condemn any indiscriminate attacks and targeting of civilian infrastructure, including hospitals and Australia joins with others in calling for international law to always be upheld."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese says 'every innocent life matters'

document.caption: The Prime Minister condemns "indiscriminate" attacks on civilian buildings and says respect for humanitarian law is "paramount".

children.content: The Prime Minister condemns "indiscriminate" attacks on civilian buildings and says respect for humanitarian law is "paramount".

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese commented on the Gaza hospital blast during a joint press conference with Fijian Prime Minister
Sitiveni Rabuka, who is visiting Canberra.
"We have seen a devastating loss of innocent life since the attacks on Israel by the terrorist group Hamas," Mr Albanese said.
"The scenes from the explosion at a Gaza City hospital are deeply distressing and it is clear that there has been a devastating loss of life.
"Every innocent life matters, whether it is Israeli or Palestinian.

"Our thoughts are with those killed, those injured and their loved ones. The protection of civilian lives must come first, as the parliament said in its resolution that we carried on Monday, and respect for international humanitarian law is paramount.
"We condemn any indiscriminate attacks and targeting of civilian infrastructure, including hospitals and Australia joins with others in calling for international law to always be upheld."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden says he is "outraged" by the explosion at al-Ahli Arab Hospital and said he had directed his national security team to gather information about exactly what had happened. "I am outraged and deeply saddened by the explosion at the Al Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza, and the terrible loss of life that resulted," Biden, who is on his way to Israel, said in a statement. "The United States stands unequivocally for the protection of civilian life during conflict and we mourn the patients, medical staff and other innocents killed or wounded in this tragedy."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden expresses outrage over Gaza hospital blast, says US will investigate

children.content: US President Joe Biden says he is "outraged" by the explosion at al-Ahli Arab Hospital and said he had directed his national security team to gather information about exactly what had happened.
"I am outraged and deeply saddened by the explosion at the Al Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza, and the terrible loss of life that resulted," Biden, who is on his way to Israel, said in a statement.
"The United States stands unequivocally for the protection of civilian life during conflict and we mourn the patients, medical staff and other innocents killed or wounded in this tragedy."

title.children: Nicole quit her job of 20 years to help Joey the 'one in a million' leak detection dog be his best

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: Local shares are fairly flat after a mixed session on Wall Street, while Credit Corp plunges on a profit warning. Follow the day's financial news and insights in our live blog.

title.children: Debt collector Credit Corp shares in freefall, ASX trades flat overall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 was pretty evenly split between gainers (92) and losers (89) with 18 going nowhere. But it was a few big rises that helped the broader market to a solid 0.3% rise. Whitehaven Coal is buying steelmaking coal mines off BHP and Mitsubishi, and the market clearly thinks it's getting a great deal, with its share price up 11.5% to $7.57. The market also became hopeful that Aussie winemakers like Treasury might again start getting a fair deal from the Chinese government, with that country's ambassador this afternoon hinting that punitive tariffs could soon be unwound. Treasury was up 5% to $12.23 as a result. The other big winners were: Genesis Minerals +7.4% to $1.535 Weebit Nano +6.9% to $3.11 Capricorn Metals +6% to $4.75 Neuren Pharmaceuticals +5.3% to $11.57 The big loser of the day was debt collecting giant Credit Corp, after it revealed increasing difficulties recouping moneys owed in the US, where it has a large business. Its shares were crunched 30.5% to $11.97. The other major losers were: Bapcor -7.6% to $5.46 Hub24 -5.4% to $31.77 Cromwell Property Group -3.8% to $0.38 Charter Hall Social Infrastructure REIT -2.9% to $2.64
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX rises on big gains for Whitehaven, Treasury

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What is the news on TWE - its share price has jumped. China news? - Bruce. Hi Bruce, Great observation. As reported in the AFR, China's ambassador to Australia has said that the country's punitive tariffs on Australian wine could be removed in coming weeks or months as the two governments continue thawing relations. The ambassador was speaking at an Australia-China Business Council event at Parliament House in Canberra. Treasury Wine Estates was a major exporter to China before those tariffs all but totally dried up that market overnight. Treasury shares closed up 5% at $12.23 on the ambassador's afternoon comments. Kathleen Ferguson had a great story on AM yesterday about how badly this has affected parts of the Australian wine industry, with nearly 860 Olympic-sized swimming pools of wine sitting in tanks, barrels and bottles around the country.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chinese ambassador hints that wine tariffs might end soon, Treasury shares jump

featuredLink.title: Australian winemakers optimistic about China trade  - ABC listen

children.content: What is the news on TWE - its share price has jumped. China news?
- Bruce
Hi Bruce,
Great observation.
As reported in the AFR
China's ambassador to Australia has said that the country's punitive tariffs on Australian wine could be removed
in coming weeks or months as the two governments continue thawing relations.
The ambassador was speaking at an
Australia-China Business Council
event at Parliament House in Canberra.
Treasury Wine Estates
was a major exporter to China before those tariffs all but totally dried up that market overnight.
Treasury shares closed up 5% at $12.23
on the ambassador's afternoon comments.
Kathleen Ferguson
had a great story on
AM
yesterday about how badly this has affected parts of the Australian wine industry, with
nearly 860 Olympic-sized swimming pools of wine
sitting in tanks, barrels and bottles around the country.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: China's economy has beaten expectations in the third quarter, with GDP growth coming in at 1.3% for the September quarter and 4.9% year-on-year according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Market economists had generally expected 1% and 4.4% growth respectively. But, as is often the case with official Chinese government data, many in the market are somewhat sceptical. "Our in-house China Activity Proxy (CAP) paints quite a different picture," writes Capital Economics' head of China economics Julian Evans-Pritchard. "It suggests that growth slowed from 1.3% q/q in Q2 to 1.0% in Q3 and that cumulative growth since the end of 2019 is almost 6%-pts lower than official figures claim. "But even the CAP suggests things are starting to improve again. In monthly terms, it shows that output bottomed out in June, with the economy since regaining some momentum. That's a trend that appears to have continued in September, judging by the latest activity data." And, while things may be substantially weaker than the official figures suggest, Mr Evans-Pritchard says the economic turnaround is real. " The economy has clearly turned a corner thanks to policy support. And we anticipate a further recovery over the coming quarters." ANZ's China economists Raymond Yeung and Zhaopeng Xing say this recovery may see a wind-back in economic support from the central government and policymakers. "Government officials will be feeling confident about achieving a growth target of 5%," they note. "They could therefore scale down the intensity of stimulus measures. They do see the issue of household and private sector confidence, so will stick to a more targeted approach in formulating policy, going forward. "Despite the data improvement, the output gap remains negative as indicated by weak domestic prices (CPI 0.0%). The weakness in investment suggests the real interest rate is too high. We expect the People's Bank of China to reduce the 1y Loan Prime Rate by 5bp on Friday. " They have put together a handy ready reckoner for recent Chinese economic data, which shows it's been generally positive.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China's economy 'has turned a corner' but doubt cast on GDP rebound

children.content: China's economy has beaten expectations in the third quarter, with
GDP growth coming in at 1.3% for the September quarter and 4.9% year-on-year
according to the National Bureau of Statistics.
Market economists had generally expected 1% and 4.4% growth respectively.
But, as is often the case with official Chinese government data, many in the market are somewhat sceptical.
"Our in-house China Activity Proxy (CAP) paints quite a different picture," writes
Capital Economics' head of China economics Julian Evans-Pritchard
"It suggests that growth slowed from 1.3% q/q in Q2 to 1.0% in Q3 and that
cumulative growth since the end of 2019 is almost 6%-pts lower than official figures claim

"But even the CAP suggests things are starting to improve again. In monthly terms, it shows that output bottomed out in June, with the economy since regaining some momentum. That's a trend that appears to have continued in September, judging by the latest activity data."
And, while things may be substantially weaker than the official figures suggest, Mr Evans-Pritchard says the economic turnaround is real.
The economy has clearly turned a corner thanks to policy support.
And we anticipate a further recovery over the coming quarters."
ANZ's China economists Raymond Yeung and Zhaopeng Xing
say this recovery may see a wind-back in economic support from the central government and policymakers.
"Government officials will be feeling confident about achieving a growth target of 5%," they note.
"They could therefore
scale down the intensity of stimulus measures
. They do see the issue of household and private sector confidence, so will stick to a more targeted approach in formulating policy, going forward.
"Despite the data improvement, the output gap remains negative as indicated by weak domestic prices (CPI 0.0%). The weakness in investment suggests the real interest rate is too high.
We expect the People's Bank of China to reduce the 1y Loan Prime Rate by 5bp on Friday.
They have put together a handy ready reckoner for recent Chinese economic data, which shows it's been generally positive.

title.children: Greta Thunberg arrested at climate protest outside London oil and gas forum

image.altText: Graphic of Brandon Zerk-Thatcher, Xavier Duursma, Esava Ratugolea, Jack Ginnivan and Ivan Soldo.

items.synopsis: It all comes down to deadline day for the AFL trade period, with some big moves and late surprises on the cards before the window shuts tonight. Get the latest news, analysis and discussion in our live blog.

title.children: Fan favourite Magpie joins AFL rivals as trade period deadline day drama heats up

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Port Adelaide's ruckapalooza is complete. Port Adelaide have traded pick 50 to the Western Bulldogs for Jordon Sweet. A very simple one in the end, with that pick 50 being the one that came back to Port from Richmond in the Ivan Soldo deal. Will be very interesting to see if Port now play two rucks next year, or if Sweet has headed to another club where he'll have to play second fiddle and earn his place.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jordon Sweet has been traded to Port Adelaide

children.content: (Getty Images)
Port Adelaide's ruckapalooza is complete.
Port Adelaide have traded pick 50 to the Western Bulldogs for Jordon Sweet.
A very simple one in the end, with that pick 50 being the one that came back to Port from Richmond in the Ivan Soldo deal.
Will be very interesting to see if Port now play two rucks next year, or if Sweet has headed to another club where he'll have to play second fiddle and earn his place.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Only about 24 hours since this became a possibility, it has now become real. Jack Ginnivan is a Hawk. Hawthorn have traded pick 33, a future second and future third round pick to Collingwood for Jack Ginnivan, pick 39, a future second and a future fourth round pick. Going to be absolutely fascinating to see where Jack Ginnivan's career goes from here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jack Ginnivan has been traded to Hawthorn

children.content: (Getty Images)
Only about 24 hours since this became a possibility, it has now become real. Jack Ginnivan is a Hawk.
Hawthorn have traded pick 33, a future second and future third round pick to Collingwood for Jack Ginnivan, pick 39, a future second and a future fourth round pick.
Going to be absolutely fascinating to see where Jack Ginnivan's career goes from here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Richmond have relented, the Port Adelaide offer was too good. The Power have their new frontline ruckman. Port Adelaide have traded picks 41 and 49, a future second (Freo) and future fourth to Richmond for Ivan Soldo and pick 50. A big move for a big man. Ivan Soldo should make a difference in that Port engine room next year and beyond.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ivan Soldo has been traded to Port Adelaide

children.content: (Getty Images)
Richmond have relented, the Port Adelaide offer was too good. The Power have their new frontline ruckman.
Port Adelaide have traded picks 41 and 49, a future second (Freo) and future fourth to Richmond for Ivan Soldo and pick 50.
A big move for a big man. Ivan Soldo should make a difference in that Port engine room next year and beyond.
